title: Map of Slave Trade Out of Africa - trends

content.description:
The Slave Trade Out of Africa, 1500â€“1900

The map is centered on the south Atlantic Ocean and shows the following continents:

North America

South America

Europe

Asia

Africa

The map depicts numbers of enslaved people transported from Africa to various parts of the world from 1500 to 1900. The numbers are as follows:

Note:

All numeric values are approximate.

Transportation routes merge in the mid-Atlantic Ocean such that origins and destinations may be less definite than presented here.

From West Central Africa to Brazil: 8,000,000

From West Africa and West Central Africa to the Caribbean and North America: 11,000,000. These enslaved people were transported to countries as follows:

United States: 1,000,000

Cuba: 2,000,000

Colombia and Mexico: 1,000,000

Jamaica: 4,000,000

Haiti: 2,000,000

Barbados: 1,000,000

From West Africa to North Africa: 4,000,000

From West Africa to Europe: fewer than 1,000,000

From West Africa and from the Swahili Coast of East Africa to Egypt, Arabia, Asia, and India: 8,000,000

From the Swahili Coast of East Africa and from Madagascar to the Mascarene Islands: 1,000,000

From the Swahili Coast of East Africa to Argentina: 1,000,000

The map details numbers of enslaved people transported from regions on the Windward Coast of West Africa. From east to west, the numbers are as follows:

All values are approximate.

From Senegambia: 2,000,000

From Sierra Leone: 1,000,000

From Windward Coast: 1,000,000

From Gold Coast: 2,000,000

From Bight of Benin: 4,000,000

From Bight of Biafra: 3,000,000
Adapted from map created by Henry Louis Gates, created by the Harvard Center for Geographic Analysis.
content.question: The map of the Atlantic slave trade depicts which of the following trends?

choices.label: The Atlantic slave trade primarily connected western Africa and North America.
Portugal was the leading country involved in the Atlantic slave trade during its existence.
Over time, Charleston, South Carolina, was a major hub for the Atlantic slave trade in the United States.
Fewer Africans came to the United States through the Atlantic slave trade than to other areas in the Americas.

content.answer: Fewer Africans came to the United States through the Atlantic slave trade than to other areas in the Americas.
